Question: The conventional knowledge on the edge of realization is attained only after entering the correct state of detachment from birth. Why is it said to be attained at the time of entering?

We reply, this kind of person also once had a continuity of aggregates, elements, and sense bases in the realm of form.
They experienced the retribution of this action there.
If this is so, how can the cause that is accomplished in the continuity of an Ärya be the result in the continuity of an ordinary being?
We reply, there is no error in admitting this as cause and effect,
as explained in the Treatise on the Bases of Karma.
If one is bound by both the bonds of the defilements eliminated by the path of insight and the bonds of the defilements eliminated by the path of cultivation, one can go to evil destinies.

The stream-winner has only the bonds of the defilements eliminated by the path of cultivation and lacks the bonds of the defilements eliminated by the path of insight and therefore does not go to evil destinies.
There are two kinds of causes for evil destinies:
first, the bonds of the defilements eliminated by the path of insight;
second, the bonds of the defilements eliminated by the path of cultivation.
The bonds to be eliminated by cultivation that are accomplished by all stream-enterers are indeed the causes of evil destinies.
How can it not be that the causes accomplished in the continuum of the noble ones give rise to the effects in the continuum of ordinary beings?
Therefore, what is said here is also without fault.
This says that the non-arising causes and effects can have this matter. If they can arise, there is no such matter.
There is also a saying:
The Buddha and pratyekabuddhas also have the aggregates, realms, and sense bases of the form realm like the Å›rÄvakas. Their continuums experience this fruition of the wisdom of the other shore.
The judges say that both should not speak like this.
One should say:
The conventional wisdom at the end of penetrating insight is contaminated and indeterminate, so it is said to have fruition.
But there is no meaning of having experienced it in the past or experiencing it in the future.
Therefore, one should not blame it for experiencing the fruition body.
Question: Can there be two noble ones born in the same stage, one accomplishing the conventional wisdom at the end of penetrating insight and one not accomplishing it?
Answer: There can be.
That is to say, one relies on the first meditation to enter into the correct state of separation from birth.
One relies on the second meditation to enter into the correct state of separation from birth.
They both die and are reborn in the second meditation.
One who relies on the first meditation does not accomplish this knowledge, because it is abandoned by transcending the stage.
One who relies on the second meditation accomplishes it.
This knowledge arises and is not abandoned in one's own stage.
Can there be two arhats dwelling in the same stage,
where one accomplishes the knowledge of the edge of the present insight and the conventional knowledge, while the other does not accomplish it?
The answer is: There is.

That is to say, previously one relied on the first meditation to enter into the correct state of separation from birth.ğŸ”½One relied on the second meditation to enter into the correct state of separation from birth.

Dwelling in the intermediate state, they attain the fruit of arhatship.
One who relies on the first meditation does not accomplish this knowledge, because it is abandoned by transcending the stage.

Because this knowledge is born and not abandoned in one's own stage. It is asked: When the knowledge of exhaustion is attained by Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and tathÄgatas, they all cultivate the wholesome roots of the nine stages of the three realms.

Although they all attain it, in this context, the superior wholesome roots of the desire realm are to be discussed, so the attainment of the two vehicles and other stages is not mentioned.
It is asked: Do all arhats who attain the knowledge of exhaustion cultivate the wholesome roots of the nine stages of the three realms?
The answer is: This is not definite.
If one is born in the desire realm and attains the knowledge of exhaustion, one can cultivate the future wholesome roots of the three realms and nine stages.
If one is born in the first meditative absorption and attains the knowledge of exhaustion, one can cultivate the future wholesome roots of the two realms and eight stages.
Because one born above does not cultivate the contaminated wholesome roots below.
Up to if one is born in the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception and attains the knowledge of exhaustion, one can cultivate the future wholesome roots of one realm and one stage.
Here, the wholesome roots are superior, so they are mentioned separately.
But in reality, one fully cultivates the four aggregates and five aggregates.
Question: Are these cultivations obtained through added effort, through detachment, or through birth?
Answer: They are obtained through detachment and also through added effort.
Because they are obtained when detaching from the summit of existence.
ÅšrÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas also manifest them through added effort.
But they are not obtained through birth, because they are not superior.
Question: Are these cultivations accomplished through hearing, accomplished through thinking, or accomplished through cultivation?
Answer: They are all of three kinds.
That is, those in the desire realm are accomplished through hearing and thinking.
Those in the form realm are accomplished through hearing and cultivation.
Those in the formless realm are accomplished only through cultivation.
Question: Why is the conventional knowledge at the end of the path of insight not accomplished through hearing?
Are the wholesome roots cultivated at the time of the knowledge of exhaustion accomplished through hearing?
Answer: Because that is the retinue of the path of insight, it is entirely intense, and is cultivated by the swift path, so it is not accomplished through hearing.
This is the retinue of the knowledge of exhaustion. The knowledge of exhaustion rests and seeks, and is the leisurely path, so it can universally cultivate all added efforts.

Answer: They exist only in the mind.
Because there is no preparatory wholesome [roots] in the five consciousnesses.

Therefore, they exist only in the mind.

How many are accomplished in the future?

Answer: They are present. It is said that an arhat, having seen forms with the eye,

Extending this to the mind cognizing dharmas,
he does not delight, does not sorrow, but abides in equanimity, endowed with mindfulness and clear comprehension.
For that arhat who has attained the knowledge of exhaustion, if the first wholesome eye consciousness appears in the present,
They attain one past [cognition], six future [cognitions], and one present [cognition].
This [attainment] is not relinquished upon cessation.
If a wholesome auditory cognition arises and is present,
they attain two past [cognitions], six future [cognitions], and one present [cognition].
This [attainment] is not relinquished upon cessation. Up to if a wholesome mental cognition arises and is present,

This [attainment] is not relinquished upon cessation.
Up to if a wholesome mental cognition arises and is present,
they attain five past [cognitions], six future [cognitions], and one present [cognition].
This [attainment] is not relinquished upon cessation.
If a wholesome mental cognition or another cognition arises and is present,
They attain six in the past and future, and one in the present.
How does this explanation accord with the sutra? Answer: This refers to the arising and cessation in the pure body of one who has exhausted the defilements.
It does not refer to the arising and cessation since beginningless birth and death.
However, this explanation does not contradict the wholesome roots cultivated at the time of the knowledge of exhaustion.
Furthermore, there is an explanation.

The six dharmas of constant abiding are also only in the mental realm, because it is said that having seen forms with the eyes, up to having cognized dharmas with the mind, one is neither joyful nor sorrowful, but always abides in equanimity, endowed with mindfulness and right knowledge.
If so, why is it also said that when the present wholesome eye consciousness, etc. are present, one attains one in the present?
Answer: It should be known that this refers to the practice of constant abiding, not the essence of constant abiding, so there is no contradiction.
What is the essence of the six dharmas of constant abiding?
Answer: They have mindfulness and wisdom as their essence. How do we know this?
As a sutra says: The minds of arhats who are well liberated possess six kinds of constant abiding.
What are the six?
It means that when the eye sees forms, up to when the mind cognizes dharmas, one is neither joyful nor sorrowful, but always abides in equanimity, endowed with mindfulness and right knowledge.
If one also takes the associated and coexistent [factors], then it has the nature of four aggregates or five aggregates.
The nature has already been explained.
The reason will now be explained.
Question: Why is it called always abiding? What is the meaning of always abiding?
Answer: Because all arhats always abide in this and never abandon it, it is called always abiding.
Question: Do all arhats have these six dharmas of always abiding?

Because all arhats are not without the accomplishment of this mindfulness and wisdom.

The judges say:
It should be said:

Namely, the desire realm, the preliminary stage of meditation, the intermediate meditation, the four meditations, and the four formless [absorptions]. The mental consciousness mindfulness and wisdom pervade all stages.

Question: Why does one who attains the knowledge of elimination suddenly cultivate the wholesome roots of the three realms in the future, and not at other times?
Answer: At that time, the afflictions of the three realms are eternally exhausted, and there is nothing more to be done.
Only the worldly mind of entering and emerging from samÄdhi is needed to enjoy the various samÄdhis, and therefore at this time one cultivates the wholesome roots of the three realms.
Furthermore, at this time one eternally abandons the various afflictions that had not been abandoned in the past,
and for the first time attains the various merits that had not been attained in the past. Therefore,
one is able to suddenly cultivate the wholesome roots of the three realms.
Furthermore, at this time the mind attains the sovereign position of a king, with the auspicious white silk of liberation tied on the head.
The wholesome roots of the three realms all come to pay tribute.
It is like when one ascends to the position of king and the white silk is tied on the head, all the countries come to pay tribute.
Furthermore, at this time one is able to destroy the enemy of the afflictions that had not been destroyed in the past,
and the wholesome roots of the three realms all come to congratulate.
It is like a person who can defeat the enemy's country and return to his own country.
All the people of the country come to welcome and congratulate him.
Furthermore, at this time, he can subdue the power of afflictions that have not been subdued in the past, and the wholesome roots of the three realms all rejoice and praise him.
It is like in a large assembly, if there is someone who can subdue a powerful wrestler who has never been subdued before, the assembly will all rejoice and praise him.
Furthermore, at this time, liberation is completely fulfilled, and therefore he can cultivate the wholesome roots of the three realms as an auxiliary practice.
That is to say, from the path of seeing onwards, up to the vajra-like concentration, liberation is not yet fulfilled and can only be cultivated to a certain extent as appropriate.
When attaining the knowledge of elimination, liberation is fulfilled, and therefore he can cultivate the wholesome roots of the three realms as an auxiliary practice.

It is like a person who leads water to irrigate a field. When one furrow is filled, he moves on to the next furrow, and so on, until all the furrows are filled and the water overflows, flowing everywhere else.

Furthermore, at this time, because the bonds of afflictions are exhausted, the wholesome roots of the three realms are all liberated and their power increases, and therefore they are cultivated all at once.
That is, since beginningless time, the wholesome dharmas of the three realms have always been bound by afflictions and are not free and powerful.
Therefore, one is unable to cultivate them completely. If one practices and is free from the defilements of desire, one obtains a little liberation, but many bonds remain.
Up to if one is free from the eighth category of afflictions of the peak of existence, although there is much liberation, there is still a little bondage.

If one is free from the ninth category of the peak of existence, at that time the bonds of the wholesome roots of the three realms are all severed, and one obtains mastery, so one suddenly cultivates everything.
It is like silk, etc., when bound by nine bonds, if one severs one or two up to eight, the bundle does not scatter.
When severing the ninth, the bundle then scatters. This is also like that.

Furthermore, since beginningless time, the wholesome dharmas of the three realms have all been disgusted with the afflictions of the peak of existence. Although many expedient means have been used, they have not been able to be severed.
Now, having obtained their complete severance, one suddenly cultivates them.
Furthermore, the power of the vajra-like samÄdhi increases and becomes fierce, and all afflictions are able to be eternally extinguished.
The knowledge of elimination that is induced is also able to comprehensively attain all liberations.
Therefore, in this stage one is able to comprehensively cultivate the wholesome roots of the three realms.
